title: How to say that I have passed a test, I passed or I've passed - Quora

response.answer_text: Both of these, “I passed” and “I’ve passed” a test mean basically the same thing. However, given a specific context, a speaker might choose one over the other. The first one (“I passed…”) uses the simple past tense, and gives the expression the shade of meaning that the event (passing the test) is definitely over and done with. A speaker might say it when he/she is so relieved that the test is over and he/she passed it!! So, “I studied for that test for a month, but it’s over and I passed it!! I’m so happy and relieved!” In contrast, the second option uses the present perfect tense (“I’ve passed…”). The purpose of the perfect aspect is to show the action or state of the verb in relation to another state or action. The present perfect is often used to show that the first action was recently completed. For this reason, a speaker will often use the word “just” to emphasize the closeness of the action. So, “I’ve just passed the test! I’m so relieved.” Sometimes the choice of simple past or present perfect can reflect a more obvious meaning difference. However, this is not the case here.

Both are fine, but they mean slightly different things."I passed the test" is specifically talking about the act of taking and passing that test.  It's a reference to a point in time and a specific test."I have passed the test" is more about who you are and less about that specific event.  This is a really minor difference, but it makes more sense with other scenarios.  "I ran a marathon" probably means you did it recently and you're talking about that experience.  "I've run a marathon" might just mean you won't think walking a mile to the restaurant is a big deal. But really, with all of this, most English speakers won't even notice if you use one over the other.
